Fig. 1 H2-TPR-MS profiles of the calcined catalysts. (a) and (b) were the H2-TPR profiles of the copper-based catalysts after the calcination. (c) and (d) were MS spectra of the gaseous products from H2-TPR characterization of CuO/Na/Al2O3 and CuO/Mg/Al2O3. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 CO2-TPD spectra of the reduced catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 UV–vis DRS of copper-based catalysts after calcination. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 XRD of copper-based catalysts after calcination (a, a*), reduction (b, b*) and hydrogenation at 160 °C (c, c*). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 TEM characterzation of Cu/Al2O3 after (a) calcination or (b) reduction as well as the Cu/Mg/Al2O3 after (c) calcination or (d) reduction. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Product distribution in the HMF hydrogenation catalyzed by different copper-based catalysts at 60 °C. Reaction conditions: HMF loaded: 0.1 g, deionized water loaded: 3.6 g, catalyst loaded: 0.1 g, H2: 6 MPa, T =60 °C, reaction time: 2 h. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Product distribution in the HMF hydrogenation catalyzed by different copper-based catalysts at 60 °C. Reaction conditions: HMF loaded: 0.1 g, deionized water loaded: 3.6 g, catalyst loaded: 0.1 g, H2: 6 MPa, T =60 °C, reaction time: 10 h. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 UV-fluorescence spectra of soluble polymers from HMF hydrogenation over copper-based catalysts at 60 (a) and 80 °C (b) or with the alkali metal oxides or salts (c). The concentration of the liquid was 400 ppm. The fluorescence peaks at 295–323 nm are attributed to the compounds with one to three fused benzene rings. The fluorescence peaks at 475-450 nm are attributed to the compounds with three to five fused benzene rings. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Product distribution in the HMF hydrogenation catalyzed by different copper-based catalysts at (a) 80 °C and (b) 100 °C. Reaction conditions: HMF loaded: 0.1 g, deionized water loaded: 3.6 g, catalyst loaded: 0.1 g, H2: 6 MPa, reaction time: 2 h. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Product distribution in the HMF hydrogenation catalyzed by different copper-based catalysts at (a) 120 °C and (b) 160 °C. Reaction conditions: HMF loaded: 0.1 g, deionized water loaded: 3.6 g, catalyst loaded: 0.1 g, H2: 6 MPa, reaction time: 2 h. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 In situ DRIFTS characterization of HMF hydrogenation over Al2O3 (a), Cu/Al2O3 (b), Cu/Na/Al2O3 (c) or Cu/K/Al2O3 (d). The reduced catalyst was impregnated with the aqueous solution of HMF (2.5 wt %) initially, which was then heated to a ramping rate of 20 °C/min and hold at 160 °C for 30 min in a H2 flow (40 mL/min). Fig. 11 Fig. 12 In situ DRIFTS characterization of HMF hydrogenation over Cu/Mg/Al2O3 (a), Cu/Ca/Al2O3 (b), Cu/Sr/Al2O3 (c) or Cu/Ba/Al2O3 (d). Reaction conditions are the same as that in Fig. 11. Fig. 12 Fig. 13 In situ DRIFTS-MS spectroscopy of the pyrolysis experiment of the catalyst absorbed HMF. (a) Al2O3; (b) Cu/Al2O3; (c) Cu/Mg/Al2O3. Reaction condition: The reduced catalyst was impregnated with the aqueous solution of HMF (2.5 wt %) initially, which was then heated to a ramping rate of 10 °C/min and hold at 600 °C for in a N2 flow (40 mL/min). The effluent gaseous products were monitored with a one-line MS. Fig. 13 Scheme 1 The proposed main reaction pathways for the hydrogenation of HMF over (a): Cu/Al2O3 and (b): Cu/M/Al2O3. Cu-based catalysts for hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural: Understanding of the coordination between copper and alkali/alkaline earth additives Kai Sun a Yuewen Shao a Qingyin Li a Qianhe Liu a Weibing Wu a Yi Wang b Song Hu b Jun Xiang b Qing Liu c Xun Hu a ⁎ a School of Materials Science and Engineering, University of Jinan, Jinan 250022, PR China School of Materials Science and Engineering University of Jinan Jinan 250022 PR China b School of Energy and Power Engineering, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430074, PR China School of Energy and Power Engineering Huazhong University of Science and Technology Wuhan 430074 PR China c Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Energy and Chemical Engineering, College of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, Shandong University of Science and Technology, Qingdao 266590, PR China Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Energy and Chemical Engineering College of Chemical and Environmental Engineering Shandong University of Science and Technology Qingdao 266590 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract This study investigated impacts of alkali or alkaline earth metals additives (Na, K, Mg, Ca, Sr or Ba) on the physicochemical properties and catalytic behaviors of Cu/Al2O3 catalyst in hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). Na or K addition to Cu/Al2O3 led to the decreased specific area via merging of the small pores and the partial transformation of γ-Al2O3 into AlOOH phase. Na, K or Mg addition could drastically increase the activity for hydrogenation of HMF to 2,5-dihydroxy methyl furan (DHMF) at low temperatures (i.e. 60 °C), possibly attributing to the increased weak alkaline sites and the synergetic effects between the additives and copper. In addition, the additives could effectively suppress the hydrogenolysis or the opening of furan ring, retaining DHMF, the major initial product from HMF hydrogenation, in the reaction medium. The in situ DRIFTS of hydrogenation of HMF and in situ DRIFTS-MS of thermal treatment of HMF indicated the presence of the additives significantly impacted the reaction intermediates formed during the hydrogenation of HMF. Keywords 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural Hydrogenation Copper-based catalysts Alkali or alkaline earth additives Coordination effects 1 Introduction 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), a downstream product from hydrolysis of cellulose in biomass [1,2], is regarded as one of the key platform molecules for synthesizing a variety of value-added chemicals via hydrogenation, acid-catalysis, oxidation, etc. [3–7]. Hydrogenation of HMF could produce various fine chemicals, such as 2,5-dihydroxy methyl furan (DHMF) [8], 2, 5-dimethylfuran (DMF) [9], and 2,5-dihydroxy methyl tetrahydrofuran (DMTHF) [10], which can serve as the staring materials for manufacturing pharmaceutical intermediates [11]. HMF possesses a hydroxyl group, carbonyl group and a furan ring, which are reactive during hydrogenation reaction [12]. In principle, the hydroxyl group could be removed via hydrogenolysis, while the carbonyl group and furan ring could be saturated via hydrogenation. Furthermore, the furan ring could be opened to form aliphatic compounds [13]. These various conversion routes created difficulties for selective conversion of HMF to a specific compound [14,15]. Therefore, it is of importance to develop the catalysts with excellent hydrogenation performance to achieve the selective transformation of HMF to targeting products. Noble metal-based catalysts, such as Pt [16,17], Pd [18,19], or Ru [20,21], are highly active towards the full hydrogenation of HMF to 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF), methylated furans or other compounds [22–24]. However, noble metal-based catalysts could not be applied in large-scale in industry due to their high cost. Copper-based catalysts have been investigated extensively for hydrogenation reactions, owing to its lower cost and the remarkable activity towards hydrogenation of the furans like furfural to furfuryl alcohol [25]. Nevertheless, depending on the catalytic properties of catalysts and reaction conditions, the furan ring in furfuryl alcohol produced might be further hydrogenated [26]. Similar phenomenon could also be observed in the hydrogenation of HMF over the copper-based catalysts [27]. How to tailor the selectivity of copper catalysts is of importance for achieving highly selective conversion of HMF. Catalytic performances of copper catalysts are mainly determined by catalyst formulation, preparation methods, reaction conditions, etc. [28]. In formulation of copper-based catalysts, additives play important roles in determination of catalytic performances. For example, additives could interact with coppers, promoting its reduction or dispersion [29,30], or could modify the acidity/alkalinity of support [31]. Acidic or basic sites in copper-based catalysts have strong influences on the conversion of furans during hydrogenation [32]. This is because the acidic/basic sites could not only impact the activity for hydrogenation [33] but also catalyzed the polymerization, dehydration reactions and the opening of the furan rings during hydrogenation [34–36]. These reactions are the major factor affecting distribution of the products from hydrogenation of furans. However, how does the acidity/alkalinity of support surface affect catalytic behaviors of copper-based catalysts in HMF hydrogenation has not been fully understood yet. In this study, Cu/Al2O3 was used as the model catalyst and the impacts of a series of alkali or alkaline earth additives (Na, K, Mg, Ca, Sr and Ba) on its physicochemical properties and catalytic behaviors in hydrogenation of HMF were investigated in detail. The catalysts were characterized with temperature program reduction (TPR), temperature program desorption (TPD), temperature program oxidation (TPO), N2-adsorption-desorption, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscope (TEM) and UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectrophotometry (UV–vis DRS). The reaction intermediates formed during the hydrogenation reactions were investigated via an in situ DRIFTS technique. The results showed that the coordination between copper and the alkali or alkaline earth metal additives played key roles in enhancing the activity in the low temperature region and in balancing the hydrogenation and hydrogenolysis reactions. Specially, the addition of K or Na to Cu/Al2O3 could increase the yields of DHMF from ca. 4% to 90% at 60 °C. The addition of K, Na, Mg and Sr could also prevent DHMF from the further hydrogenation and the rearrangement of the furan rings. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials γ-Al2O3 (specific surface area: 219 m2/g, pore volume: 0.75 cm3/g, average pore radius: 3.1 nm, purchased from Zibo Hanlu environmental protection and technology Co., Ltd.) was used as the support for the copper catalysts. Cu(NO3)2, NaNO3, KNO3, Mg(NO3)2, Ca(NO3)2, Sr(NO3)2 and Ba(NO3)2 were analytical grade and were used directly without any further pretreatment. 2.2 Catalysts preparation Cu/M/Al2O3 catalysts (M = Na, K, Mg, Ca, Sr or Ba) were prepared via a two-stage incipient wetness impregnation method. The solution of Cu(NO3)2 (0.3 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 3.5 g of H2O) and nitrate solution (the amount of nitrate was weighed to achieve a ratio of MxOy to Al2O3 of 6 wt %) were prepared. 5 g of dried γ-Al2O3 was immersed into the nitrate solution to prepare the M/Al2O3 precursors at room temperature. The impregnated precursors were then dried at 100 °C and then calcined at 600 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min in static air. After that, M/Al2O3 was immersed into Cu(NO3)2 solution to load Cu species. Cu(NO3)2/M/Al2O3 precursors were then dried at 100 °C for 12 h and calcined at 300 °C for 2 h with a ramping rate of 10 °C/min. Prior to the hydrogenation experiments, the Cu/M/Al2O3 catalyst was reduced in a H2 stream (flow rate: 50 mL/min) at 300 °C for 1 h, and was cooled to room temperature under N2 atmosphere and then in hydrogenation of HMF. 2.3 Hydrogenation experiments Hydrogenation of HMF was operated in an autoclave made of 316 stainless steel materials. In a typical experiment, 0.1 g of HMF and 3.6 g of H2O were mixed and charged into the reactor vessel with a 10 mL of volume. The reduced catalyst with a loading of 2.7 wt % was also loaded together with the reactants. A magneton with a stirring speed of 400 rpm was used to mix the catalyst and the reactants. Nitrogen was used first to remove the residual air inside the autoclave and hydrogen was used to flush the residual nitrogen for three times. After that, hydrogen was filled into the autoclave until the pressure rose to 3 MPa at room temperature. The reactor vessel was then heated to the pre-set temperature in ca. 30 min. When reactor reached to the required temperature, additional hydrogen was filled into the autoclave to maintain the pressure of 6 MPa and the reaction time was beginning to be recorded. When the hydrogenation experiment was over, the reactor was cooled down to room temperature via a cooling water running inside the reactor. After reactions, all the substances including liquid products and catalysts were dissolved in ethanol with the measured mass and then solid catalysts were separated from the mixture by centrifugation. The solid catalysts were dried in a vacuum oven at 80 °C after being washed with deionized water and ethanol respectively, by three times and later were used in the further analysis. 2.4 Characterizations N2-adsorption-desorption isotherms curves and pore distribution of the catalysts were measured with an aperture specific surface area analyzer (Beijing BJbuilder electronic technology Co. Ltd, SSA-6000). The specific surface area was obtained with the method of Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and the pore size distribution was evaluated by the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Reduction behaviors of the catalysts were evaluated in H2-TPR and the oxidation characters of the reduced catalysts were detected in O2-TPO. Alkaline on the surface of catalysts was tested by CO2-TPD. TPR, TPO and TPD were measured by a chemical adsorption analyzer (Beijing BJbuilder electronic technology Co. Ltd, PCA-1200). XRD (Rigaku, Ultima IV) was conducted to characterize the structural configuration of the catalysts after impregnation, calcination, reduction and the use in hydrogenation. The diffraction angle was set from 5.00 to 80.00° with a step of 0.02° and a scanning speed of 20°/min. TEM was used to observe micro-morphology of the calcinated and reduced catalysts by employing a TEM microscope (JEOL2010). The reaction intermediates during hydrogenation of HMF over the copper-based catalysts were studied by using the Nicolet iS50 Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) instrument which was equipped with an in situ DRIFTS cell (Thermo Fisher Scientific). DRIFTS-MS was conducted to study the desorption of HMF on the surface of the reduced catalysts. The gaseous desorption/decomposition-products from the real-time response were detected by a mass spectrometry (Pfeiffer, MS GSD 320). UV-Vis DRS of all the calcined catalysts were characterized with a UV–vis spectrophotometer (Beijing Puxi Instrument Factory, T9). BaSO4 was used as a standard reference. The synchronous spectra of soluble polymer with the π-conjugated structure formed from polymerization of HMF during the hydrogenation process were measured by a fluorescence spectrometer (Shimadzu, RF-6000). The initial excitation wavelength was set to 230 nm and always remained 20 nm away from the emission wavelength. In addition, the scanning speed was set to 600 nm/min. Prior to the test, the liquid sample collected after the hydrogenation were diluted to 400 ppm with absolute ethanol. The concentration/abundance of the polymer in ethanol to the signal intensity had a linear response. The liquid products were analyzed with a GC–MS instrument (Shimadzu, GCMS-QP2020) fitted with a Wax pillar column (film thickness: 0.25 μm, internal diameter: 0.25 mm, length: 30 m). The conditions for measuring the products were listed as below: the temperature of vaporization chamber: 250 °C, the temperature of column: maintained at 50 °C for 3 min and then increased to 250 °C at 10 °C/min, the solvent to dilute the samples: acetone. The different substances in the samples were separated according to the boiling point and polarity. Furthermore, the identification of the compounds will be achieved by matching mass spectrum with the standard spectra library in the NIST 2014. The definitions of HMF conversion and product yield were shown below: H M F c o n v e r s i o n ( % ) = M o l e o f H M F c o n s u m e d M o l e o f H M F l o a d e d × 100 % The product yield/selectivity was calculated according to the equation as follows: P r o d u c t y i e l d ( % ) = M o l e o f p r o d u c t M o l e o f H M F l o a d e d × 100 % P r o d u c t s e l e c t i v i t y ( % ) = M o l e o f p r o d u c t M o l e o f H M F c o n s u m e d × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Surface and pore volume analyses The BET surface area, pore volume, average pore size and pore distribution were shown in Table 1 and Figure S1, respectively. Comparing with alumina support (Entry 1, Table 1), the BET surface area and pore volume of the Cu/Al2O3 (Entry 2, Table 1) as well as Cu/M/Al2O3 catalysts (Entry 3–8, Table 1) decreased remarkably. The loading of copper and the alkali or alkaline earth metals filled the pores of the catalysts, reducing the specific area and the pore volume. However, the average pore sizes did not change much for the Cu/Al2O3 catalyst (Entry 2, Table 1), but even increased remarkably for the Na or K modified catalysts (Entry 3 and 4, Table 1). These results indicated that the pores being filled were probably the micropores. The increased average pore size of Cu/K/Al2O3 and Cu/Na/Al2O3 catalyst was probably due to the merge of the small pores, induced by the addition of Na or K to the catalysts. The N2-adsorption-desorption-isotherms of all the catalysts (Figure S1a) after calcination were consistent with type IV from IUPAC [37,38], indicating the support could maintain the mesoporous structure after modified by alkali and alkaline earth metals. In addition, Figure S1a showed the pressure at the end of the loop from Cu/Al2O3 was lower than that of Al2O3 or Cu/Al2O3 modified by alkali and alkaline earth metals, which indicated that the addition of metals protected some small-sized pores from blocking of copper. The addition of the alkali and alkaline earth metals not only affected the porous structures of the catalysts, but also the reduction behaviors of copper oxide, which will be further discussed. 3.2 H2-TPR H2-TPR profiles for the copper catalysts were shown in Fig. 1 a and b. There were two reduction peaks for the reduction of the copper oxides in Cu/Al2O3, suggesting the presence of two types of Cu species or due to the consecutive reduction of CuO to Cu2O and then to Cu (Fig. 1a and b). In the latter case, the amount of hydrogen consumption from the reduction of CuO to Cu2O and Cu2O to Cu should be close. Nevertheless, the peak area of the two peaks varied significantly, which thus should belong to two types of CuO. The first type with the reduction peaked at ca. 303 °C was probably ascribed to the reduction of CuO that had weak interactions with Al2O3. The second reduction peak (at ca. 337 °C) was probably allied to the reduction of the CuO having a stronger interaction with Al2O3. In addition, the cycled TPR-TPO results confirmed the presence of two types of copper species in Cu/Al2O3 catalyst (Figure S2). With the addition of the additives, the main reduction temperatures of CuO shifted to a higher region (Fig. 1a and b). These additives probably induced a stronger interaction between Cu species and Al2O3. The XRD results, which will be discussed below, showed that SrAl2O4 and CuAl2O4 were formed, respectively, in Cu/Sr/Al2O3 and Cu/Ba/Al2O3 catalysts. The additives changed the surface properties of the catalysts, which further affected the interaction between copper and alumina. Reduction degree of the catalysts were calculated and showed in Table 1. It was unexpected that the reduction degree of the samples was beyond 100% and that of Cu/Na/Al2O3 and Cu/Mg/Al2O3 exceeded 500% (Entry 3 and 5, Table 1). The hydrogen consumed was far more than that required for the reduction of the CuO in the catalysts. H2-TPR-MS of the Cu/Na/Al2O3 and Cu/Mg/Al2O3 (Fig. 1c and d) was performed to investigate the origin for the excessive consumption of hydrogen. The results shown in Fig. 1c and d indicated that CO and CO2 were generated during the reduction of the catalysts. CO2 in air could be absorbed on the surface of Al2O3 during the calcination of the catalysts. During the reduction of the catalyst, CO2 could be converted to CO via water gas shift reaction (CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O), which consumed hydrogen and led to extremely high reduction degree. The absorption of CO2 on surface of the catalysts was due to the alkalinity induced by the addition of the alkali and alkaline earth metals, which was further characterized via CO2-TPD. 3.3 CO2-TPD CO2-TPD was employed to explore the basic sites on surface of the reduced catalysts. The results were shown in the Fig. 2 . The CO2 desorption peaks in the regions of 50–200 °C, 200–600 °C and 600–900 °C could be assigned to the basic sites with weak, medium and strong strength. The additives significantly modified the distribution of the basic sites across surface of the alumina carrier. The normalized abundance of the CO2 desorbed in the different temperature regions was calculated and summarized in Table S1. Cu/Al2O3 possessed the weak and medium basic sites on the surface of γ-Al2O3. Respectively, the basic sites of weak, medium and strong strength are ascribed to OH group, Mn+–O2− (M was a neighboring metal ion) and isolated O2- ions [39]. The total number of basic sites increased remarkably with the presence of the additives, as shown in Table S1. In general, the addition of Na, K or Mg improved the abundance of the weak-strength basic sites, which was probably due to the enrichment of the species with electron donation effects with the addition of the oxides of the additives. The addition of Sr and Ba increased the abundance of the medium and strong basic sites. It indicated that Mn+–O2− took part in the formation of the basic sites. SrAl2O4 and CuAl2O4, which was detected by XRD, could prove that the addition of Sr and Ba changed the interaction between the metal and oxygen species. The electronegativity of oxygen ions from the surface of alumina were enhanced after modifying with the alkali or alkaline earth metals, which had a lower electronegativity than Cu and Al [40]. The distinct impacts of the additives on distribution of the basic sites might impact the catalytic performance of the catalysts for hydrogenation of HMF, which will be discussed later. 3.4 UV–vis DRS UV-vis DRS shown in Fig. 3 indicated that Al2O3 exhibited no peak in the region of 200–800 nm, but Cu/Al2O3 after calcination-treatment had an absorbance at 202 nm which was attributed to the charge transfer transition from O2−→ Cu2+ [41]. This signal shifted to 204–209 nm in the spectra of the copper-based catalysts with the addition of the alkali and alkaline earth metals. Besides, a characteristic absorption peak at 666 nm, which was assigned to d–d transitions from the copper atom [42], was observed in the modified catalysts. It was due to that the addition of alkali or alkaline earth metals affected the interaction between copper and alumina, thus affecting the coordination between copper and oxygen atom. 3.5 XRD and TEM Fig. 4 showed the XRD spectra of the catalysts after calcination, reduction and the use in hydrogenation of HMF. γ-Al2O3, CuO and the nitrate additives were detected in the samples after calcination. The nitrates of the additives were impregnated firstly and calcined at 600 °C, and these nitrates might decompose completely at such a high temperature. Nevertheless, the presence of the nitrates of the additives after the impregnation of Cu(NO3)2 and calcination at 300 °C was quite unexpected. The NaNO3/Al2O3 after drying at 100 °C and calcination at 600 °C was characterized with XRD. The results shown in Figure S3 to confirm that, under the calcination temperature of 600 °C, the NaNO3 could decompose completely. Nevertheless, after loading Cu(NO3)2 via impregnation, the NaNO3 species appeared again. It was assumed that the following consecutive reactions took place. NaNO3 →2 Na2O + 4 NO2↑ + O2↑ (calcination at 600 °C) Na2O + H2O →2 NaOH (during the impregnation of Cu(NO3)2) 2 NaOH + Cu(NO3)2 → 2 NaNO3 + Cu(OH)2↓ (during the impregnation of Cu(NO3)2) The occurrences of such reactions would result in the change of Cu precursor from Cu(NO3)2 to Cu(OH)2 in the preparation of the catalyst. In addition, the formation of the nitrates during the impregnation of Cu(NO3)2 also contributed to the exceedingly high reduction degree of CuO (Table 1). This was because the reduction of the nitrates also consumed hydrogen, as evidenced in Fig. 4b and b*, the nitrates were removed via reduction of the catalysts with hydrogen. Fig. 4c and c* showed that γ-Al2O3 was not stable at 160 °C under the hydrothermal conditions in the hydrogenation process, which was transformed into γ-AlOOH. Alumina as the support can provide the porous structure for dispersion of copper. The change of its structure would inevitably impact the catalytic behaviors of the catalysts. The grain size of copper oxide after the calcination and that of metallic copper after the reduction and hydrogenation of HMF were shown in Table S2. The particle size of CuO was remarkably smaller than that of metallic Cu. Evidently, aggregation of the metallic Cu took place during the reduction of the catalysts. The presence of Mg, Ca, Sr and Ba could suppress the sintering of Cu to some extent. The presence of Mg could suppress the aggregation of the copper oxide during the calcination process. TEM characterizations of the bare and Mg modified catalysts after calcination and reduction were shown in Fig. 5 . There are some fibrous structures which belonged to probably alumina in all the samples. For the calcinated Cu/Al2O3 (Fig. 5a) and Cu/Mg/Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. 5c), the diameter of the fiber of the former was bigger than that of the latter, which indicated the addition of Mg could suppress the growth of the fibrous structures. Similarly, the fibrous structures in the Mg modified copper catalyst exhibited a smaller size than that of bare one in the reduction process (Fig. 5b and d). As discussed above, the alkali and alkaline earth metals as the additives significantly affected the physiochemical properties of the copper catalysts. This would inevitably impact the catalytic activity for hydrogenation of HMF, which was further investigated. 3.6 Impacts of the additives on the catalytic activity Fig. 6 shows the product distribution in the hydrogenation of HMF over different alkali and alkaline earth metals modified copper-based catalysts at 60 °C. In the absence of copper, alumina itself showed a neglected capability for the hydrogenation of HMF. However, Cu/Al2O3 also showed a low activity for hydrogenation of HMF, due to the low reaction temperature employed. Nevertheless, the modification of the catalyst with the additives especially Na, K or Mg drastically increased the low-temperature activity for the hydrogenation of HMF to DHMF (Fig. 6). With a prolonged reaction time, the yield of DHMF reached ca. 90% over the Na or K modified catalyst at the temperature as low as 60 °C (Fig. 7 ). Mg as the additive also showed promotional effects on the activity of the catalyst for the hydrogenation reactions. In comparison, Ca, Sr or Ba as the additive could promote the capability of the catalyst for hydrogenation, while the promotional effects of the additives like Na, K and Mg were insignificant. For the Na, K or Mg modified catalysts, the abundance of the weak basic sites increased significantly among these catalysts (Table S1), which possibly enhanced the activity of the catalysts. As indicated from the results of CO2-TPD, the addition of alkali or alkaline earth metals increased the abundance of basic sites on surface of the catalyst, which helps to facilitate the interaction with HMF that contains an electron-withdrawing carbonyl group [43]. Hydrogen activated on metallic Cu sites into might migrate and give preference to hydrogenate the C = O of HMF due to the electron-withdrawing effect, as proposed in Scheme 1 . It needs to be noted that Scheme 1 is a proposed route and is speculative, and further study is required to confirm this. To our best knowledge, HMF is prone to polymerization at elevated temperatures [44]. The soluble polymers formed from the polymerization of HMF during the hydrogenation were characterized with a UV-fluorescence spectrometer, which were shown in Fig. 8 a and b. The peak at 301 nm corresponded to the π-conjugated structures with one to three fused rings, while that at 404 nm corresponded to the π-conjugated structures with three to five rings [45]. In the aqueous medium, the opening of the furan ring in HMF and the following isomerization could produce the phenolic compound (pathways V, Scheme 2 ). The intermediates and the phenolic compounds could continue to cross-polymerize with HMF to form the soluble polymer [46]. The products in Scheme 1 could be found in GC spectra (Figure S4 and S5). The proposed reaction pathways were shown in Scheme S1 and S2. As shown in Fig. 8a, the addition of Na did not dramatically affect polymerization of HMF at 60 °C. In comparison, Mg addition promoted the polymerization and Ba addition suppressed the polymerization reactions. During the hydrogenation of HMF, the polymerization of HMF could take place simultaneously, which is undesirable and should be prevented. Fig. 9 a showed the product distribution in the hydrogenation of HMF over different copper-based catalysts at 80 °C. Increasing the reaction temperature to 80 °C improved the activity of the catalysts for hydrogenation of HMF, especially for the Na, K or Mg modified catalysts. These three catalysts also showed the activity for hydrogenolysis, as evidenced by the formation of MF from the cracking of COH bond in HMF molecule. Similarly, the promotional effects of Ca, Sr or Ba on the catalytic activity were not prominent. The increase of the reaction temperature to 100 °C further increased activity of the catalysts (Fig. 9b). Cu/Al2O3 catalysts exhibited a good activity for hydrogenation of HMF to DHMF in this stage. Over the Cu/K/Al2O3 catalyst, the highest yield of DHMF was obtained. The further increase of reaction temperature to 120 °C resulted in the further improvement of the activity of hydrogenation, especially over the Sr or Ba modified catalysts (Fig. 10 a). In principle, the hydrogenolysis of HMF to MF and the hydrogenation of HMF to DHMF were competitive reactions, while the former reactions were greatly suppressed at this stage. Increasing the reaction temperature to 160 °C, however, significantly changed the reaction network (Fig. 10b). Alumina itself showed almost no activity for hydrogenation reactions, but exhibited the activity for the dehydrogenation to produce 2,5-diformyl furan (DFF) (Fig. 10b). The presence of Cu on alumina (Cu/Al2O3) increased the hydrogenation activity of the catalysts. Nevertheless, the DHMF over Cu/Al2O3 was further hydrogenated to 5-methyl dihydrofurfuryl alcohol (MDHFA) and 5-methyl cyclopentanol, as shown in Figure S4. The proposed reaction pathways for the further hydrogenation of DHMF were shown in Scheme 2. It was clear that 5-methyl furfuryl alcohol (MFA) was the potential intermediate product from the hydrogenolysis of DHMF. MFA could be fully hydrogenated to produce MTHFA, or be partially hydrogenated to produce MDHFA. MFA could also be converted to 5-methyl cyclopentanol via opening of the furan ring and rearrangement of the intermediates. It was interesting that the full hydrogenation product of HMF, DMTHF (pathway I, in Scheme 2), was not the main product. On the contrary, the hydrogenolysis of one of the hydroxyl group in DHMF was the dominant pathway for the further conversion of DHMF. The main product distributions from hydrogenation of HMF over alumina or the modified catalysts were shown in Figure S5. In comparison, even at the temperature as high as 160 °C, majority of the DHMF were not further hydrogenated over the copper catalysts modified with the additives except Ca (Figure S5e). The Ca modified catalysts promoted the conversion of HMF via opening of the furan rings, which should mainly attribute to the properties of Ca species but not to the alkalinity. MFA was the main intermediate for the conversion DHMF to MTHFA and 5-methyl cyclopentanol. The results herein indicated that the presence of Na, K, Mg, Sr and Ba could suppress the hydrogenolysis of DHMF to MFA. The selectivity relates to the preference of the catalysts for the hydrogenation of CO or the hydrogenolysis of CO from HMF. The modification of the catalysts with the basic additives increased the alkalinity of the catalyst, which would facilitate the selective absorption of the carbonyl group due to its electron-withdrawing effect, and thus promotes the hydrogenation of HMF instead of the hydrolysis. This was probably the main reason for suppression of the hydrogenolysis reactions over the alkali or alkaline earth metal catalysts. 3.7 Synergistic effect between copper and the additives The above results showed that the additives, especially the Na, K or Mg modified catalysts showed excellent catalytic performances for the hydrogenation of HMF to DHMF at the low reaction temperatures (i.e. 60 or 80 °C). This might be caused by the synergistic effects between copper active site and the additives, which would be further investigated by hydrogenation of HMF with the co-presence of Cu/Al2O3 catalyst and the corresponding salts or alkalines. The XRD characterizations did not indicate the existing form of the alkali and alkaline earth metal species on surface of the catalysts. Considering that the alkali oxides exist in the form of hydroxides in aqueous solution, sodium hydroxide and potassium hydroxide instead of sodium oxide and potassium oxide were used. NaNO3 and KNO3, which are neutral salts, were also used for comparison. The conversion of HMF over the Cu/Al2O3 catalyst and the corresponding salts, alkalines or oxides mixed were shown in Table 2 . The results showed that the alkalines or the oxides had little activity for the hydrogenation. The trace amount of DHMF was probably formed from the Cannizaro reaction of HMF in the presence of the base. Compared with the blank control group (Entry 7, Table 2), the conversion of HMF was relatively low with NaNO3 or KNO3 as the catalysts, while was much higher with alkaline or basic oxides as the catalysts. The liquid products were characterized with UV-fluorescence to explore the potential routes for the conversion of HMF. The results shown in Fig. 8c indicated that some soluble polymers with π-conjugated structure were formed, suggesting the polymerization of HMF. In the blank experiments or the experiments with NaNO3 or KNO3 as the catalysts, the polymerization of HMF was much milder. The hydroxides or the oxides of the additives could promote the conversion of HMF, but mainly via polymerization reactions. Cu is essential for the occurrence of the hydrogenation. The hydrogenation of HMF over the co-existence of Cu/Al2O3 catalyst and the hydroxides or oxides in the reaction medium was further preformed and the results were shown in Table 3 . Comparing with only Cu/Al2O3 catalyst, the presence of the hydroxides or oxides could remarkably enhance the conversion of HMF via hydrogenation. The hydroxides or oxides might help to activate HMF to some reaction intermediates, which were subsequently hydrogenated over the Cu sites. The alkalinity played crucial roles in enhancing the catalytic activity of the catalysts. As shown in Entry of 5 and 6 in Table 3, with KNO3 or NaNO3 as the additives, the catalysts expressed a neglectable activity for hydrogenation of HMF. The loading of the additives to Cu/Al2O3 catalysts showed even much superior activity for hydrogenation of HMF. The coordination of the additives with Cu clearly existed. The alkalinity of the additives played crucial roles in enhancing the low-temperature activity of the catalysts for hydrogenation of HMF. 3.8 In situ FT-IR analysis The in situ DRIFTS study of hydrogenation of HMF was also performed at the temperatures up to 160 °C to probe the change of the functionalities of HMF during the hydrogenation. The results were shown in Figs. 11 and 12 . Alumina did not show activity for hydrogenation reactions and the carbonyl group was retained with the increase of the reaction temperature to 160 °C (Fig. 11). The intensity of hydroxyl group at ca. 3321 cm−1 decreased with the temperature being increased, which was attributed to the damage of water from HMF solution adsorbed by the catalysts. The higher temperature made the catalysts to express wore hydrophobicity [47] and thus probably affected the property of HMF on the surface of the support. In addition, the absorption of the C = C, C–O–C, and CHx also became significant at the higher reaction temperature, indicating the transformation or polymerization of HMF on the surface of alumina at the higher temperature. Over Cu/Al2O3 catalyst, the hydrogenation of HMF took place, as evidenced by the remarkable decrease of the absorption of the carbonyl functionalities, especially at 160 °C. In comparison, the absorption of CHx increased significantly, which was in line with the results shown in Fig. 13 b, where the full hydrogenation of HMF and the hydrogenolysis reactions occurred, producing the furans and cyclopentanes with the −CH3 or −CH2 functionalities. The relative abundance of carbonyl functionalities over the Na or K modified catalysts was lower than that over the Cu/Al2O3 catalyst (Entry 2–4, Table 4 ). These catalysts showed good hydrogenation activities and the carbonyl could be hydrogenated well below 160 °C, which was also in line with the results shown in Figs. 6–9. The absorption of the CHx over the modified copper-based catalyst was not as significant as that over the Cu/Al2O3 catalyst, which further confirmed that the modification of the catalyst with Na or K could suppress the deep hydrogenation of the furan ring and the hydrogenolysis of the hydroxyl group. The addition of Mg modified the absorption of the intermediates. The absorption appeared at 1796 cm−1 belonged to the CO absorbed on the catalyst [48]. For the Ca, Sr or Ba modified catalyst, the absorption of the carbonyl functionalities did not change much, which was due to their relatively lower activity for the hydrogenation of HMF. Specially, over the Ca modified catalyst, the absorption of the CHx became significant at 160 °C, indicating the occurrence of the deep hydrogenation reactions, which was similar to the results shown Fig. 10b. The dissociation of HMF over alumina, Cu/Al2O3 and Cu/Mg/Al2O3 in N2 atmosphere at the temperature up to 600 °C was measured by in situ DRIFTS-MS. The evolution of the carbonyl functionality varied significantly over the different catalysts. The carbonyl functionality was stable at the temperature up to 300 °C over Al2O3 or Cu/Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. 13a and b), while over Cu/Mg/Al2O3 its transformation initiated at ca. 200 °C (Fig. 13c). New CC in the aromatic ring structures were formed, accompanying by the polymerization or cracking of HMF at the higher temperature. Strong absorption of the COC aliphatic structures were observed over alumina but not over Cu/Al2O3 and Cu/Mg/Al2O3, suggesting that Cu species could interfere with the formation of COC aliphatic structures on surface of the catalysts. The MS results showed that over Al2O3 (Figure 13a*) there were some CO2, CO and CH4 formation during the thermal treatment. CO2 was probably from desorption of the CO2 physically absorbed on alumina. CO and CH4 were probably from decarbonylation or decomposition of HMF. Cu/Al2O3 catalyst changed the pathways for the decomposition of HMF (Figure 13b*). The formation of CO appeared at a higher temperature and two desorption peaks for CO2 were observed. The addition of Cu changed the distribution of the basic sites, and stronger absorption of CO2 was observed. In addition, the formation of hydrogen indicated the occurrence of the dehydrogenation of probably the hydroxyl group together with the associated methylene group. Over Cu/Mg/Al2O3, the relative abundance of the gaseous products formed was much less when compared with that of Cu/Al2O3 catalyst. The formation of hydrogen via the dehydrogenation reactions only took place at ca. 450 °C (Figure 13c*), indicating that the addition of Mg could strongly enhance the absorption/interaction of HMF or the functionalities of HMF. The strong absorption of HMF over the alkali or alkaline earth additives modified catalysts would significantly impact the reaction pathways of HMF during the hydrogenation, as the results presented above. 4 Conclusions In summary, the results presented above showed that the addition of the alkali and alkaline earth metals significantly affected the physiochemical properties and catalytic behaviors of the Cu-based catalysts. The addition of Na or K to Cu/Al2O3 led to the decreased specific area via the merge of the small pores and the transformation of γ-Al2O3 phase into AlOOH. Nevertheless, aggregation of the metallic Cu took place during the reduction of the CuO to metallic Cu while the presence of the additives could suppress the sintering of Cu to some extent. In addition, the addition of Na, K and Mg increased the abundances of the basic sites with weak strength, while the addition of Ca, Sr or Ba could remarkably increase the abundances of the basic sites with medium to strong strength. The modification of the catalyst with Na, K or Mg could drastically increase activity for the hydrogenation of HMF to DHMF in the low temperature region, while the promotional effects of Ca, Sr or Ba were not that remarkable. The additives also significantly impacted the selectivities of the catalysts. Over the unmodified Cu/Al2O3 catalyst, the further hydrogenolysis of the hydroxyl group in DHMF and the formation of 5-methyl cyclopentanol, via opening of the furan ring and rearrangement of the intermediates were the dominant pathways for the further conversion of DHMF. In converse, majority of the DHMF were not further hydrogenated and retained in the reaction medium over the copper catalysts modified with the additives. The modification of the catalysts with Na, K or Mg as the additives increased the weak alkalinity and enhanced the electron-donor property of the hydroxyl group on the surface of alumina, which would facilitate the selective absorption of the carbonyl group due to its electron-withdrawing property, and thus promote the hydrogenation of HMF instead of the hydrolysis. This was probably the main reason for achieving the high selectivity for DHMF instead of its further transformation over these modified catalysts even at the high temperature. The coordination effects of the additives with Cu existed. The additives might help to activate HMF to some reaction intermediates, which were subsequently hydrogenated over the Cu sites. The in situ DRIFTS of hydrogenation of HMF and in situ DRIFTS-MS of thermal treatment of HMF indicated that the presence of the additives could strongly absorb the reaction intermediates and remarkably impact the reaction pathways of HMF during the hydrogenation reactions. The results in this study showed that the alkalinity of the additives, especially the weak basic sites, played crucial roles in enhancing the low-temperature activity and in determining the selectivity of the catalysts for hydrogenation of HMF. How do the alkalinity of the Cu-based catalyst or other transition metal based catalysts affect their catalytic behaviors in other hydrogenation reactions need further investigation. coredata.dc:description: This study investigated impacts of alkali or alkaline earth metals additives (Na, K, Mg, Ca, Sr or Ba) on the physicochemical properties and catalytic behaviors of Cu/Al2O3 catalyst in hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF). Na or K addition to Cu/Al2O3 led to the decreased specific area via merging of the small pores and the partial transformation of γ-Al2O3 into AlOOH phase. Na, K or Mg addition could drastically increase the activity for hydrogenation of HMF to 2,5-dihydroxy methyl furan (DHMF) at low temperatures (i.e. 60 °C), possibly attributing to the increased weak alkaline sites and the synergetic effects between the additives and copper. In addition, the additives could effectively suppress the hydrogenolysis or the opening of furan ring, retaining DHMF, the major initial product from HMF hydrogenation, in the reaction medium. The in situ DRIFTS of hydrogenation of HMF and in situ DRIFTS-MS of thermal treatment of HMF indicated the presence of the additives significantly impacted the reaction intermediates formed during the hydrogenation of HMF.
coredata.dc:title: Cu-based catalysts for hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural: Understanding of the coordination between copper and alkali/alkaline earth additives
